page.title: 20 The Cuningar Loop
page.content: This is a large area of vegetation situated only 4km. from the city centre, where the Clyde cuts a big meander on the south bank. It is generally flat, about 6 metres above river level. Old mine shafts run underneath and subsidence has taken place. Dumping stopped about 15 years ago and nature has almost reclaimed the area. Plants such as giant hogweed, japanese knotweed, butter burr and willowherb cover the site. There are also thickets of goat willow , hawthorn and elder. If left the area could revert to oak forest. Wildlife is abundant - heron, mallard, fox, rabbit, mouse and mole. Mostly used by dogwalkers and naturalists, its future is undecided. At present when Glasgow's wild areas are disappearing fast it is a valuable urban wildlife resource.
